reviewText:
Did you ever want to play Carcassone in Bob the Builder style? Then this is a game for you.

You have to manage a way for your trucks across the map, while your competitors do the same.. all the while trying to sabotage your roadway and transports. Therefore are two main types of utilities you can use. One are the road types from normal road to bridge and tunnels, which your trucks use, while the others are destructive tools to sabotage your opponents, these range from dynamite, nails up to police controls, emp bombs, radar and much more.

The gameplay is made up to four players at one map, while it can already get quite hectic with only two players, while you try to keep the balance between sabotaging and guarding your own. While there are some single player maps (which the first 8 mainly work as a tutorial) the main game is the multiplayer part against other human opponents.

Conclusio:
As one game usually doesnt take too long, for a quick play against some friends this can be quite a fun distraction.

Note: This game was reviewed with a key given by the developers

reviewText:
Detour claims to be an addictive competitive real time strategy game, however, I would say almost none of that is true.
There is not much strategy involved aside from 'build roads everywhere you can to block everyone' (Goldmines first so you can afford to keep blocking them), and 'throw explosives at the other players'. When dealing with a strategy game, I tend to want more than that. So I can not say it is good at that.
As for competitive, don't bother. It does not have a lot of skill involved aside from who can build the fastest(Which in itself is a matter of being the fastest at clicking). There is very little here that would be competitive, or that would draw anyone wishing to be competitive. There are way better things out there.
Addictive? Definitely not. Play it once, maybe twice. Third time with friends and then you´ve seen it all. There is nothing to come back for, and I would say it is severely lacking in replay value.

At least it is realtime, and with 4 players throwing explosives it is chaotic so you can at least count that as a plus if you enjoy that sort of thing. For the single player challenges, they do take some effort, though the 'humour' involed in it is certainly not my kind. You are essentially challenged by a bunch of stereotypes which eventually end up teaming up on you. And then it just sort of ends.

Detour is a game that sounds good in theory, but just doesn't cut it in practice. Maybe it was a good idea on the idea board that just didn't get fleshed out right, maybe they just lacked the skill or knowledge to make it work. But either way I would recommend against buying Detour - Your time is more valuable than any sale price

reviewText:
DETOUR is an RTS. You build roads to lead your trucks to the finish line while the enemy team does the same. You can disrupt each other with things like missiles and sentry turrets.
Controls
Since it's a top down perspective game, you have camera controls which are the WASD keys and mouse to place your buildings and roads. Navigating through different buildables is a hassle. They're categorized into roads, aggressive offensive weapons like missiles, placeable weapons like turrets and truck upgrades. The buildables have each their own hotkeys. It's extremely hectic.

Sounds
The music is awful. It's generic and gets really annoying after a while. On top of that, the music usually doesn't fit the mood. While I was given a briefing during the tutorial, the song was intense and felt like it was out of an action movie. When playing a multiplayer free-for-all game, the song reminded me of a calm spring afternoon with its peaceful piano melody.
Sound effects were not as terrible. Pretty regular stuff if you ask me. Lifeless without much spice but did its job.

Graphics
Horrible. The menus seem to be work in progress. The font choice is bad, text starts from wherever and server browser is a background image of a table with text on top which doesn't even line up with the background. It doesn't help that white is a dominant color and the text is not outlined with a darker color.
In-game graphics are simplistic and nothing like the standards today. GUI looks like a mess with garbage visual appearance and placing. Maps are squares in an empty space. Objects are placed on a grid on the square. Effects are simple and nothing looks special. It's dull and unpleasant to look at.

Balance
Non-existent. Some maps are not balanced fairly to all players. Some maps are symmetrical and some have three player bases on one side and the last player sits alone in one corner. The AI is either not challenging or already sending its second truck while you're pondering where the second road tile should go to. Everything has a low cooldown so things like missiles can be launched almost constantly. Money doesn't really seem to run out because everything is quite cheap. Though, you can change the income rate and starting cash but I went with defaults.

Other
The broken lobbies. I wasn't sure what was going on first but nothing seems to work properly. It's like that old 1960's TV which you had to give a good whack on the side to make it show clear image. When you select a color, it changes randomly. Sometimes the ready button doesn't work at all. Some game modes can't have more than one player. In a coop mode. reviewText:
-Quick Review-
DETOUR is a real-time highway-simulator strategy-game developed by Sandswept Studios. The objective can be summed up as “get this truck across the finish line, on the other side of the map”. DETOUR gets increasingly complex with weapons, buildings, and opposing AI or Human Players (in Multiplayer).
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=505839112


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You work for a construction company over seen by not-bob-the-builder. I can't actually remember that guys name, I just know he sure looked like bob the builder, but wasn't friendly at all.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=505842603
As you progress through the game you are faced with different NPC's who are competing with you to get their trucks across the finish line. Sometimes they're all facing the same direction, other times you're pitted head-to-head with 3 NPC's against you.

Gameplay: DETOUR itself starts out very simple, and attempts to teach you the basic concepts as you play through, although the explanations are quite wordy and I concluded “I'll learn the hard way, I don't feel like reading”. (Yes, yes, shame on me. I didn't feel like dealing with Bob-the-not-builder's putting me down even though I did nothing but succeed for the company! *spit*)
As in most real-time strategy games, you reach a point where you can no longer click fast enough to compete, so you need to learn the keyboard shortcuts to keep up with the other players/AI. Unfortunately the keyboard short cuts are 1234567890 and some of the “F1-F2-F3-etc.” keys.
There are four categories of “build-able” objects; Roads, Trucks, Weapons, and Buildings. Roads are are used to cross different map terrain. Various truck upgrades can be purchased to speed up or defend your trucks. Weapons can be used to destroy, or impede other players/AI progress. And Buildings are limited but you can build ground turrets, air turrets, satellites and more.
Multiplayer can be challenging and fun, however getting to that point is a whole new kind of headache. Naturally there are connection problems depending on the physical location of the person you're playing with, but just trying to CONNECT to that persons game can take nearly five minutes. And then sometimes you might get disconnected from that persons game.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=504388340
Not to mention you need to probably arrange a game with a friend, since there aren't enough people playing the game that you can just drop in and play with a random person.

Achievements: Now we come to my biggest complaint about this game... the achievements are painfully tedious. There are 28 achievements in DETOUR. After beating the game for the first time I had literally 4 achievements.
Most of the achievements in DETOUR are actually exclusively unlocked in multiplayer mode. And none of them are quick unlocks, you need to coordinate with 3 other people for some achievements, but a handful of achievements can be unlocked with just another person (1 vs 1 matches).

Price: DETOUR is priced at $4.99, for an indie game that's a pretty fair price. I personally like to spend one hour in game for every dollar, that will easily show up on my game time, because... ...unfortunately connecting to a 4 player game requires about five minutes of restarting and reconnecting DETOUR.
The single player campaign will take about an hour or two, depending on how good you are at strategy games.

Conclusion: Story: irrelevant – I didn't feel like reading the day I did the campaign. A tiny note in my defense; a game should make you WANT to know more about the story, and this game failed in that aspect. Gameplay: the core mechanics were mostly solid, but there were graphical errors, and multiplayer connection problems. Achievements: Agonizingly long to work on these and un-soloable. Not an easy 100% completion game. Price: the price is a little high for how much time the average player will spend on the game.

All in all, DETOUR has a number of flaws and I haven't particularly enjoyed playing it. That probably means most “normal” people won't like playing it. However if you're looking for a game to play with a friend, this will give you several hours of entertainment, and even more hours of connection problems.
I recommend this game to Indie-Game Supporters, Strategy-game-fans, and achievers who aren't daunted by several hours of coordinating with others to obtain 100% completion.

reviewText:
Neat idea with poor execution. This game could be a lot of fun, but I'm still trying to figure out if the developers have even tried playing the game. The interface is clunky. Hot keys change your selection but don't take action. For instance you use WASD to move your view around the map and one of the most important tools, sensor sweep, is mapped to F2. Makes sense - your fingers are already in that general vicinty, however pressing F2 doesn't do the sensor sweep, it just makes the sensor sweep the selected action. You then have to hit the enter key which is clear across the keyboard from F2.

For single player, the first real mission after training is, as far as i can tell, unbeatable. AI opponents with no truck goals will target you, even if you also have no goals, over the AI opponent who is about to win. I tried several different strategies to foil the AI, including not completing my final road segment until a truck just needs that last segment; still no good. Learned all of the hot keys (such as they are) and the speedup still wasn't enough. I outspend all of the AIs, I nuke the AIs whenever I can... doesn't matter. There are 3 of them and one of you. There are a bunch more single player missions after that, but I've not seen them. The single player is just broken.

For multiplayer... my son and I played a few games, and while it was a little fun, the turret balance is completely off. Offensive turrets fire too fast and have too much health. They aren't taken out with a nuke and they can destroy roads as fast as you can build them. Defensive turrets are way too weak to be effective and the game quickly becomes an offensive turret race. It's cute for a little while, but quickly becomes boring.

I don't feel ripped off, I had about 1 hour of fun and the game was incredibly inexpensive; I am disappointed that a laundry list of seemingly simple and obvious improvements are still missing that could make this a reasonably fun game.

reviewText:
While this isn't a sort of game I expect to find on Steam, I was somewhat surprised at how much I enjoyed playing DETOUR.

Sempai Studios had given me a free key (thank you) and while it took me a while to get around to playing it (sorry!) this ended up being a remedy to what ended up being a particularly painful recovery day.

DETOUR reminds me a lot of the PC board games I used to play as a 90s little girl when I wasn't quite into bigger gaming. You've got the main goal (reach the end) and you have to go up against the AI with varying levels of difficulty. It's not difficult in theory. The farther you progress, the more power ups you earn. Building and power ups take points. Patience is rewarded but patience can be what causes your bitter defeat.

You're not going to be too entirely impressed with the artwork of the characters you meet in this game. The characters are very cartoony in style, but for something I'd call a time management board game, I don't find that part too important. You might. You need to know this. The actual playing field looks like your average grid filled with general pixelated grass, cityscape, rubble, etc. It's not entirely impressive. It's there. It's your playing field and it's enough for me.

Personally, I had a little bit of issue with relying on my mouse so there seemed to be something slowing me down with clicking on things. I'm not sure if it was because I'm unused to seeing an orange cone as my pointer or if there were actual mouse problems. I ended up being pretty happy to use the keyboard when I could. Clicking wasn't always my friend in this game.

Otherwise, I really enjoyed myself. The games are very short to play and they are made so that a lot of action happens at once. There are a few unique personalities to deal with, but otherwise there's not really much of a story there. It's more like a bland, shell of a story. It's more like the sort of stories you're expecting from time management games you download to kill an hour from a certain website that has a lot of HOGs. You get a few laughs from some of the text and you proceed to simply play the game. That's how it works.

Some players may find this boring and stop after the first part of the game, as yes, the easy section of the game is easy to blow through. You could purchase this for friends during the Summer Sale and use this just for playing against friends. This is a good choice if you're not into anything with gore (though most of us are, guilty as charged). Then again, those of us who are board game addicts (also guilty as charged) might enjoy this, too.

Of course then there's taking joy in finding ways to completely obliterate your opponent and dominate the field so they can't build. Being that sadistic is a sort of joy that comes from the game, as is the quick win or the slow and agonizing type of defeat. It's not hard to win, it's just the matter of how to get there. You'll learn, but it's about thinking quickly and ensuring there will be a victory.

It's a game I'll likely revisit from time to time because you can pick it up and put it down. Though I'd rather give this a sort of lukewarm rating, what tips it over is I did like it and I'll certainly be playing during my I AM JUST SO BORED!" between treatments and napping.

reviewText:
This is a good game and I can highly recommend getting it if it is on sale.

The game is great with friends and a real laugh.
The competition between each other is really enjoyable and working together as a team against bots (because there aren't many other players online) is also great.

The single player starts off easy but on challenge 10 you get repeatedly attacked by the other bots and have to focus your resources on repairing your route and stopping the others but you can never build fast enough to beat the team furthest from you. ( I am most probably just terrible at the game but after like 10 attempts it's becoming increasingly frustrating and less fun)

The soundtrack is really nice too and takes away the stress.

You should totally get this game with friends, especially if it's going for 15p. I don't know whether i'd pay £3.99 but you can always refund your money if you don't enjoy it.

Edit: After playing some more I have come to realise it's very buggy at times and would definitely not  pay £3.99.

In the turret mode, you can build on one lane and neglect the others with no consequence. The rocks cost 6 credits and stop one truck, the turrets cost 5 credits and can shoot at trucks and also stop them through contact like the rocks, making the rocks seem very pointless. It's very easy and slow moving, it gets boring very quickly. It only ended because the game thought I was in another gamemode and it said the time had run out and no one had won, it then displayed the scoreboard with only 0s because it didn't register what I had built.

Multiplayer doesn't let you do all of the modes and despite it saying 'max players 4' etc it doesn't let you do survival or turret mode with a friend.

One last complaint is that the bombs generate too quickly, they're basically the same as dynamite and can damage more structures at once so the enemy can spam bombs and destroy everything you have faster than you can rebuild and get a truck through/retaliate. Turrets have way too much health too and the bombs don't seem to do any more damage than dynamite on them, the most effective way i've found is just to spam roads until you get near it then add your own turret with aid of dynamite.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Detour with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

Detour is a puzzle game which tasks you with creating a safe route for a truck to pass through a hostile city.
Now the bad part. This game runs atrociously. The first thing that struck me when starting up the game for the first time is the inexcusable amount of latency when using the software cursor. The delay between my mouse movement and the cursors response on the screen varied anywhere from 0.5 to (not exaggerating) 2.5 seconds! If you’re really desperate to play Detour, your first priority should be to enable Hardware Cursor in the options menu. Following the debacle with the laggy mouse, I noticed there were a fair few grammatical issues with the level selection text. Typically with low budget/hobby games I sort of just overlook this, especially when the narrative is, for all intents and purposes, irrelevant to the actual gameplay. Unfortunately, after seeing the issues with the cursor, these errors were much more eye catching and set a precedent in my mind that this was either shoddily put together or unnecessarily rushed to release. Then I began the campaign. I actually quit midway through the first level just to activate Steams’ FPS counter and boot up Fraps to confirm my suspicions: this isometric mobile-port style puzzle game was running at 16 FPS on a GTX 680 and an overclocked i7-2600k. I suffered on through a handful more levels just to know what the game was trying to be, and as intriguing as the concept may be, the performance of this game is just abysmal.

reviewText:
Detour is an odd game. First off, it’s based around multiplayer, but unless you have played through the first couple of single player missions, you have no idea what’s going on. Another thing I noticed right off was the framerate. On a computer with a Core i5 processor, 16 GB of RAM, and a GPU with 2 GB of RAM of its own, I was getting 16 frames per second. On a computer that’s about 4 times the system requirements! However, once the game started, it didn’t disappoint. While the graphics aren’t the best, especially running at 16 frames per second on the lowest settings, the gameplay was fantastic.

The goal of the game is to get a certain number of trucks from your factory to the other side of the map using roads and tunnels. However, your opponent can try to stop you through many methods. One of these is by bribing the police to stop your trucks. After getting sufficiently angry, retaliation can be had by bombing your fellow opponent off of the face of the earth. Mad at the fog of war? No problem! Just run a scan! Don’t want to be scanned? Jam the signal! Don’t want your opponents getting across wetlands? Just fund the local conservation foundation! The fun in this game truly lies in the simplicity of the gameplay, but the complexity the game can take on when played by two skilled players.

After all this, I give this game a thumbs up. It may not be the most visually appealing, but it’s all it set out to be: a good RTS based around semi trucks. I never thought I’d ever type that last sentence, but there it is. Anything can happen.

reviewText:
Detour is a real-time strategy game where your goal is to get three trucks from your base to the opposite side of the map. Watch out for dynamite that destroys road, missiles that take out your trucks, and other hazards that others may send at you.

It's kind of an interesting premise, that leads to some interesting, fast-paced gameplay. That said, when there were four players desparately fighting for the middle ground, it was incredibly hard to figure out what was going on at any given time. I'd be repairing roads in one part the map while the other half was getting shredded by the AI. Half the time, the bridges and tunnels didn't work as I expected, and I didn't realize my roads weren't connecting.

Sadly, this ends up as an amateur attempt at a strategy game. There's a good idea here, but it's not well-designed, and as a result, really isn't all that fun and not terribly engaging for fans of strategy. It seems like it would be mildly entertaining as a dumb multiplayer game, since the frantic action could make some fun moments with friends, but I think that's about the only value you'll find here. If this looks interesting, check out Sid Meier's Railroads!, which is buggy and flawed but much more fun.

reviewText:
If I were to say one thing I'd definitely remove the idea of chess from the description. A game of Detour can get quite frenetic. A word you can never use to describe chess. The way detour fully works only becomes apparent after you've played it for a bit. You have to get your trucks to the other side but also stop the other people getting theirs across using bombs, turrets etc. and it can end up getting quite frenetic and violent as you juggle the many balls you have in the air all at once.

You will not have time to make considered moves, you will have to react and battle, and battle quickly to be the winner. It's very much a short form game.

It feels a little iOS-y and the graphical and musical style is really not to my taste, but once you get under the hood, there's meat on the bones.
